name: muddywater

procedures: T1003.001::[MuddyWater] has performed credential dumping with [Mimikatz] and procdump64.exe.
T1003.004::[MuddyWater] has performed credential dumping with [LaZagne].
T1003.005::[MuddyWater] has performed credential dumping with [LaZagne].
T1016::[MuddyWater] has used malware to collect the victim’s IP address and domain name.
T1027.003::[MuddyWater] has stored obfuscated JavaScript code in an image file named temp.jpg.
T1027.004::[MuddyWater] has used the .NET csc.exe tool to compile executables from downloaded C# code.
T1027.010::[MuddyWater] has used Daniel Bohannon’s Invoke-Obfuscation framework and obfuscated PowerShell scripts.
T1033::[MuddyWater] has used malware that can collect the victim’s username.
T1036.005::[MuddyWater] has disguised malicious executables and used filenames and Registry key names associated with Windows Defender.
T1041::[MuddyWater] has used C2 infrastructure to receive exfiltrated data.
T1047::[MuddyWater] has used malware that leveraged WMI for execution and querying host information.
T1049::[MuddyWater] has used a PowerShell backdoor to check for Skype connections on the target machine.
T1053.005::[MuddyWater] has used scheduled tasks to establish persistence.
T1057::[MuddyWater] has used malware to obtain a list of running processes on the system.
T1059.001::[MuddyWater] has used PowerShell for execution.
T1059.003::[MuddyWater] has used a custom tool for creating reverse shells.
T1059.005::[MuddyWater] has used VBScript files to execute its [POWERSTATS] payload, as well as macros.
T1059.006::[MuddyWater] has used developed tools in Python including [Out1].
T1059.007::[MuddyWater] has used JavaScript files to execute its [POWERSTATS] payload.
T1071.001::[MuddyWater] has used HTTP for C2 communications.
T1074.001::[MuddyWater] has stored a decoy PDF file within a victim's `%temp%` folder.
T1082::[MuddyWater] has used malware that can collect the victim’s OS version and machine name.
T1083::[MuddyWater] has used malware that checked if the ProgramData folder had folders or files with the keywords "Kasper," "Panda," or "ESET."
T1087.002::[MuddyWater] has used cmd.exe net user /domain to enumerate domain users.
T1090.002::[MuddyWater] has controlled [POWERSTATS] from behind a proxy network to obfuscate the C2 location.
T1102.002::[MuddyWater] has used web services including OneHub to distribute remote access tools.
T1104::[MuddyWater] has used one C2 to obtain enumeration scripts and monitor web logs, but a different C2 to send data back.
T1105::[MuddyWater] has used malware that can upload additional files to the victim’s machine.
T1113::[MuddyWater] has used malware that can capture screenshots of the victim’s machine.
T1132.001::[MuddyWater] has used tools to encode C2 communications including Base64 encoding.
T1137.001::[MuddyWater] has used a Word Template, Normal.dotm, for persistence.
T1140::[MuddyWater] decoded base64-encoded PowerShell commands using a VBS file.
T1190::[MuddyWater] has exploited the Microsoft Exchange memory corruption vulnerability (CVE-2020-0688).
T1203::[MuddyWater] has exploited the Office vulnerability CVE-2017-0199 for execution.
T1204.001::[MuddyWater] has distributed URLs in phishing e-mails that link to lure documents.
T1204.002::[MuddyWater] has attempted to get users to enable macros and launch malicious Microsoft Word documents delivered via spearphishing emails.
T1210::[MuddyWater] has exploited the Microsoft Netlogon vulnerability (CVE-2020-1472).
T1218.003::[MuddyWater] has used CMSTP.exe and a malicious INF to execute its [POWERSTATS] payload.
T1218.005::[MuddyWater] has used mshta.exe to execute its [POWERSTATS] payload and to pass a PowerShell one-liner for execution.
T1218.011::[MuddyWater] has used malware that leveraged rundll32.exe in a Registry Run key to execute a .dll.
T1219::[MuddyWater] has used a legitimate application, ScreenConnect, to manage systems remotely and move laterally.
T1518.001::[MuddyWater] has used malware to check running processes against a hard-coded list of security tools often used by malware researchers.
T1518::[MuddyWater] has used a PowerShell backdoor to check for Skype connectivity on the target machine.
T1547.001::[MuddyWater] has added Registry Run key KCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\SystemTextEncoding to establish persistence.
T1548.002::[MuddyWater] uses various techniques to bypass UAC.
T1552.001::[MuddyWater] has run a tool that steals passwords saved in victim email.
T1555.003::[MuddyWater] has run tools including Browser64 to steal passwords saved in victim web browsers.
T1555::[MuddyWater] has performed credential dumping with [LaZagne] and other tools, including by dumping passwords saved in victim email.
T1559.001::[MuddyWater] has used malware that has the capability to execute malicious code via COM, DCOM, and Outlook.
T1559.002::[MuddyWater] has used malware that can execute PowerShell scripts via DDE.
T1560.001::[MuddyWater] has used the native Windows cabinet creation tool, makecab.exe, likely to compress stolen data to be uploaded.
T1562.001::[MuddyWater] can disable the system's local proxy settings.
T1566.001::[MuddyWater] has compromised third parties and used compromised accounts to send spearphishing emails with targeted attachments to recipients.
T1566.002::[MuddyWater] has sent targeted spearphishing e-mails with malicious links.
T1573.001::[MuddyWater] has used AES to encrypt C2 responses.
T1574.002::[MuddyWater] maintains persistence on victim networks through side-loading dlls to trick legitimate programs into running malware.
T1583.006::[MuddyWater] has used file sharing services including OneHub to distribute tools.
T1588.002::MuddyWater has made use of legitimate tools ConnectWise and Remote Utilities to gain access to target environment.
T1589.002::[MuddyWater] has specifically targeted government agency employees with spearphishing e-mails.

description: [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) is a cyber espionage group assessed to be a subordinate element within Iran's Ministry of Intelligence and Security (MOIS).(Citation: CYBERCOM Iranian Intel Cyber January 2022) Since at least 2017, [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has targeted a range of government and private organizations across sectors, including telecommunications, local government, defense, and oil and natural gas organizations, in the Middle East, Asia, Africa, Europe, and North America.(Citation: Unit 42 MuddyWater Nov 2017)(Citation: Symantec MuddyWater Dec 2018)(Citation: ClearSky MuddyWater Nov 2018)(Citation: ClearSky MuddyWater June 2019)(Citation: Reaqta MuddyWater November 2017)(Citation: DHS CISA AA22-055A MuddyWater February 2022)(Citation: Talos MuddyWater Jan 2022)
